critters.name: White-tailed Deer
critters.summary: Common woodland browser often seen near fields and feeders.
critters.fact: White-tailed deer use their tail as a warning signal by flashing its white underside.
critters.activeFact: In winter, deer conserve energy by moving less and bedding in sheltered spots to block wind and snow.

critters.name: Black Bear
critters.summary: Largest forest mammal in Michigan woodlands.
critters.fact: Black bears have an excellent sense of smell, helping them locate food over miles in the forest.
critters.activeFact: Black bears are strong climbers and can scale trees quickly, even as full-grown adults.

critters.name: Coyote
critters.summary: Adaptable predator common in rural areas.
critters.fact: Coyotes can adapt to various habitats, from deserts to urban areas, showcasing their incredible survival skills.
critters.activeFact: Coyotes often hunt by trotting steadily for long distances, listening for movement under snow or brush.

critters.name: Red Fox
critters.summary: Solitary hunter active in open woods and fields.
critters.fact: Red foxes use their bushy tails for balance and to keep warm in cold weather.
critters.activeFact: Red foxes can pinpoint prey under snow by sound, then make a clean pounce to break through the crust.

critters.name: Gray Fox
critters.summary: Smaller fox species able to climb trees.
critters.fact: Gray foxes can climb trees to escape predators, a rare ability among North American canids.
critters.activeFact: Gray foxes can rotate their forepaws to grip bark, letting them climb more like a cat than a dog.

critters.name: Bobcat
critters.fact: Bobcats have excellent night vision, helping them hunt efficiently in low-light conditions.
critters.activeFact: Bobcats often stash leftovers by covering them with leaves or snow, then return later for round two.

critters.name: Porcupine
critters.fact: Porcupinesâ€™ quills detach easily and embed in predators as a defense mechanism.
critters.activeFact: Porcupines have iron-rich enamel that gives their front teeth an orange color and extra toughness.

critters.name: Beaver
critters.fact: Beavers build dams using trees and mud, creating ponds that provide habitat for many other animals.
critters.activeFact: A beaver tail-slap is basically a watery alarm bell, warning others to dive and disappear.

critters.name: Muskrat
critters.summary: Small aquatic rodent near ponds and streams.
critters.fact: Muskrats build dome-shaped lodges from vegetation, providing shelter and protection in wetlands.
critters.activeFact: Many muskrat lodges have underwater entrances, letting them come and go with less predator risk.

critters.name: Mink
critters.fact: Minks have waterproof fur that helps them hunt aquatic prey with ease.
critters.activeFact: A mink can switch from swimming pursuit to land ambush in seconds, depending on what bolts first.

critters.name: Fisher
critters.fact: Fishers are skilled tree climbers and use their agility to hunt squirrels and birds in forests.
critters.activeFact: Fishers move with quick stop-and-go bursts, slipping through cover so fast you might only see a shadow.

critters.name: River Otter
critters.summary: Playful aquatic predator found near rivers.
critters.fact: River otters have thick fur that traps air, keeping them warm and buoyant while swimming underwater.
critters.activeFact: Otters use sensitive whiskers to detect water movement, helping them find fish in cloudy or dark water.

critters.name: Eastern Gray Squirrel
critters.fact: Eastern Gray Squirrels use tail flicks to communicate warnings about nearby predators to other squirrels.
critters.activeFact: Gray squirrels often zigzag when running, making it harder for hawks and foxes to line up a strike.

critters.name: American Red Squirrel
critters.fact: American Red Squirrels fiercely defend their territory and food caches from intruders year-round.
critters.activeFact: They build cone piles called â€œmiddens,â€ basically a tiny forest pantry with serious attitude.

critters.name: Chipmunk
critters.summary: Ground squirrel known for cheek pouches.
critters.fact: Chipmunks can store food in expandable cheek pouches to carry home for later.
critters.activeFact: Chipmunks make quick, stop-start dashes between cover, using logs and brush like little highways.

critters.name: Snowshoe Hare
critters.summary: Forest rabbit with seasonal coat change.
critters.fact: Snowshoe hares change fur color seasonally for camouflage, white in winter and brown in summer.
critters.activeFact: Their coat changes seasonally for camouflage, but timing can vary with weather and daylight patterns.

critters.name: Eastern Cottontail
critters.fact: Eastern Cottontails can run up to 18 miles per hour to escape predators.
critters.activeFact: Cottontails often use the same brushy escape routes repeatedly, memorizing safe lanes through cover.

critters.name: Raccoon
critters.fact: Raccoons have exceptionally nimble front paws, allowing them to open jars and manipulate complex objects with ease.
critters.activeFact: Given time, raccoons can learn simple latches and lids, turning camps and feeders into puzzle boxes.

critters.name: Opossum
critters.fact: Opossums have more teeth than any other North American land mammal, with up to 50 teeth.
critters.activeFact: Theyâ€™re well-known tick eaters and also have a low body temperature, which makes rabies less common in them.

critters.name: Striped Skunk
critters.summary: Night forager known for defensive spray.
critters.fact: Striped skunks can spray a foul-smelling liquid up to 10 feet to deter predators.
critters.activeFact: Most skunks warn first with stomps, tail lifts, and a little shuffle before they commit to the stink.

critters.name: Flying Squirrel
critters.fact: Flying squirrels glide using a special membrane called the patagium stretched between their limbs.
critters.activeFact: They steer mid-glide with tiny shifts and use the tail like a rudder to land on the right trunk.

critters.name: Little Brown Bat
critters.fact: Little Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects mid-air with incredible precision during nighttime hunts.
critters.activeFact: On a good night, a little brown bat can catch a huge number of insects, helping around wetlands and lights.

critters.name: Big Brown Bat
critters.fact: Big Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects mid-flight, consuming up to half their body weight nightly.
critters.activeFact: Theyâ€™re tough and adaptable, sometimes staying active later into cool weather than smaller bat species.

critters.name: Barred Owl
critters.summary: Woodland owl known for 'who cooks for you' call.
critters.fact: Barred Owls have distinctive hoots that sound like "Who cooks for you? Who cooks for you all?"
critters.activeFact: Their flight is quiet thanks to soft feather edges that muffle sound, helping them hunt by surprise.

critters.name: Great Horned Owl
critters.fact: Great Horned Owls have ear tufts that help them blend into treetops while hunting at night.
critters.activeFact: They often reuse old nests from hawks or crows, basically moving into a pre-built â€œtree apartment.â€

critters.name: Blue Jay
critters.summary: Bold feeder visitor with loud calls.
critters.fact: Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away other birds and protect their territory.
critters.activeFact: They can mimic hawk calls, which sometimes clears a feeder faster than a â€œreservedâ€ sign.

critters.name: Northern Cardinal
critters.fact: Northern Cardinals are one of the few North American birds where females also sing.
critters.activeFact: Cardinals often sing early at dawn, even before full daylight, especially during late winter and spring.

critters.name: Black-capped Chickadee
critters.fact: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food throughout winter.
critters.activeFact: On cold nights, chickadees can lower their body temperature to save energy, then warm back up by morning.

critters.name: Tufted Titmouse
critters.fact: Tufted Titmice mimic the calls of other birds to communicate and defend their territory.
critters.activeFact: They commonly grab one seed, fly to cover, crack it open, then return again like itâ€™s a timed job.

critters.name: White-breasted Nuthatch
critters.summary: Tree climber often moving headfirst down bark.
critters.fact: White-breasted Nuthatches can climb down trees headfirst, unlike most other birds.
critters.activeFact: They wedge seeds into bark cracks, then hammer them open, basically doing tiny woodworking at the feeder.

critters.name: Downy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Downy Woodpeckers drum on trees to communicate and establish territory using rapid, rhythmic tapping sounds.
critters.activeFact: Their skull and tongue structure help absorb impacts, letting them peck repeatedly without injury.

critters.name: Hairy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Hairy Woodpeckers use their long tongues to extract insects from deep tree bark crevices.
critters.activeFact: They can pry deeper into bark than smaller woodpeckers, using strong chisel-like beaks to reach insects.

critters.name: Pileated Woodpecker
critters.fact: Pileated Woodpeckers create large rectangular holes in trees while searching for ants and beetle larvae.
critters.activeFact: Old pileated holes often become nest or den sites for other wildlife later, from owls to squirrels.

critters.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
critters.fact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers drum loudly to communicate and establish territory in forests and woodlands.
critters.activeFact: Theyâ€™re quick and assertive, often grabbing a mouthful and bouncing to a nearby trunk to eat in cover.

critters.name: Mourning Dove
critters.fact: Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 mph, making them one of North Americaâ€™s fastest birds.
critters.activeFact: Their wings can whistle on fast takeoff, a sudden sound that often happens when theyâ€™re startled.

critters.name: American Goldfinch
critters.fact: American Goldfinches molt twice a year, changing from bright yellow in summer to dull olive in winter.
critters.activeFact: Their flight looks bouncy and wave-like, and once you spot it, you can identify them in seconds.

critters.name: Dark-eyed Junco
critters.fact: Dark-eyed Juncos change song patterns to communicate effectively in noisy urban environments.
critters.activeFact: They do a two-footed backward scratch in leaf litter, kicking food free like tiny feathered bulldozers.

critters.name: House Finch
critters.fact: House Finches were originally native to the western U.S. but now thrive across much of North America.
critters.activeFact: Their songs can vary by neighborhood, and young males learn local â€œdialectsâ€ by listening.

critters.name: Purple Finch
critters.fact: Purple Finches sing a rich, warbling song that varies regionally across North America.
critters.activeFact: They often show up in bursts when cone crops are good, then vanish again into the evergreen edges.

critters.name: Wild Turkey
critters.summary: Large ground bird common in Michigan.
critters.fact: Wild turkeys can fly short distances at speeds up to 55 miles per hour.
critters.activeFact: In winter, turkeys often travel in groups and follow packed paths, saving energy when snow gets deep.

critters.name: Ruffed Grouse
critters.summary: Forest bird known for drumming display.
critters.fact: Ruffed Grouse create a drumming sound by rapidly beating their wings to attract mates and mark territory.
critters.activeFact: In snowy weather, grouse can burrow into soft snow to stay insulated and hidden from wind.

critters.name: Sandhill Crane
critters.summary: Tall wetland bird with loud call.
critters.fact: Sandhill Cranes perform elaborate, synchronized dances with their mates to strengthen pair bonds.
critters.activeFact: They strengthen pair bonds with dancing, wing spreads, and hops, especially as spring approaches.

critters.name: American Crow
critters.fact: American Crows can use tools and recognize human faces to avoid danger.
critters.activeFact: They work together to mob predators, surrounding them with loud calls until the threat leaves.

critters.name: Common Raven
critters.fact: Common Ravens can mimic sounds from their environment, including human speech and other animal calls.
critters.activeFact: They sometimes play in wind currents with rolls and dives, looking like theyâ€™re doing it for fun.

critters.name: Red-tailed Hawk
critters.fact: Red-tailed Hawks have excellent vision, spotting prey from over a mile away while soaring high.
critters.activeFact: They can spot small movement from far away, then drop in fast when a mouse or rabbit slips up.

critters.name: Cooperâ€™s Hawk
critters.fact: Cooperâ€™s Hawks are skilled fliers, hunting birds by weaving through dense trees at high speeds.
critters.activeFact: Their long tail acts like a steering wheel, letting them corner hard through branches during a chase.

critters.name: Mallard Duck
critters.fact: Mallard ducks are the ancestors of most domestic duck breeds worldwide.
critters.activeFact: They often â€œtip-upâ€ with tails in the air, head underwater, vacuuming the shallows for food.

critters.name: Wood Duck
critters.summary: Colorful duck nesting in tree cavities.
critters.fact: Wood Ducks nest in tree cavities and have colorful, iridescent plumage that shines in sunlight.
critters.activeFact: Ducklings can tumble from high nest holes and bounce off leaves and ground with little harm due to low weight.

critters.name: Canada Goose
critters.fact: Canada Geese can fly up to 40 miles per hour during migration.
critters.activeFact: Theyâ€™re fiercely protective parents and will loudly warn, posture, and charge if they think a nest is threatened.

critters.name: Great Blue Heron
critters.fact: Great Blue Herons can hunt by standing still for minutes, then striking quickly to catch fish or amphibians.
critters.activeFact: In flight, herons fold their neck into an S-shape, which is a classic silhouette once you notice it.

critters.name: Painted Turtle
critters.fact: Painted Turtles can absorb oxygen through their skin while underwater, allowing longer dives.
critters.activeFact: Theyâ€™ll slide into the water at the first hint of danger, and they can vanish faster than youâ€™d expect.

critters.name: Snapping Turtle
critters.fact: Snapping turtles have powerful jaws that can snap shut with incredible force to catch prey.
critters.activeFact: They often sit motionless on the bottom, blending in like a rock until something edible drifts close.

critters.name: Bluegill
critters.fact: Bluegill can change their spawning colors, attracting mates with bright blue and orange patterns.
critters.activeFact: They dart out for food and snap back to cover fast, using structure like a safety net.

critters.name: Largemouth Bass
critters.fact: Largemouth bass can grow over 20 inches long and use their oversized mouths to ambush prey.
critters.activeFact: They can flare their mouths wide to create suction, pulling prey in with a sudden vacuum-like gulp.

critters.name: Yellow Perch
critters.fact: Yellow Perch have distinctive vertical stripes that help camouflage them among aquatic plants and shadows.
critters.activeFact: Schooling behavior can confuse predators, and it also helps perch find food more efficiently.

critters.name: Northern Pike
critters.fact: Northern Pike can ambush prey by remaining perfectly still, then striking with explosive speed.
critters.activeFact: Pike often lurk near weed edges, then explode forward in a short burst when prey gets too close.

critters.name: Spring Peeper
critters.summary: Tiny frog with loud spring calls.
critters.fact: Spring Peepers have a loud, high-pitched call that signals the start of spring.
critters.activeFact: A peeper chorus can carry far across wetlands, even though each frog is only about an inch long.

critters.name: American Bullfrog
critters.fact: American Bullfrogs can produce loud, deep calls heard over a mile away to attract mates.
critters.activeFact: They sit at the waterline like a statue, then lunge fast to grab insects, small fish, or anything that fits.

critters.name: Green Frog
critters.fact: Green frogs use a distinctive "gunk" call to communicate, sounding like plucked banjo strings.
critters.activeFact: They usually dive at the first sign of footsteps or shadows, using the water as an instant escape hatch.

critters.name: Leopard Frog
critters.fact: Leopard frogs can jump over 10 times their body length in a single leap.
critters.activeFact: They often freeze first, then explode into a series of fast jumps toward water or thick grass.

critters.name: Garter Snake
critters.fact: Garter snakes can detect chemical cues with their tongues to locate prey and avoid predators.
critters.activeFact: When threatened, they may release a musky odor and try to slip away rather than stand their ground.

critters.name: Water Snake
critters.fact: Water snakes can stay underwater for up to an hour while hunting or avoiding predators.
critters.activeFact: They can stay still underwater to avoid detection, then move quickly when the coast is clear.

critters.name: Eastern Milk Snake
critters.fact: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous coral snakes with their colorful bands for protection from predators.
critters.activeFact: They may vibrate their tail in dry leaves when startled, creating a rattling sound as a bluff.

critters.name: Monarch Butterfly
critters.fact: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles, traveling from North America to central Mexico for winter.
critters.activeFact: Monarchs use the sun as a compass and rely on an internal clock to help keep direction during migration.

critters.name: Swallowtail Butterfly
critters.fact: Swallowtail butterflies use their tail-like wing extensions to confuse predators and avoid attacks.
critters.activeFact: They â€œtasteâ€ with sensors on their feet, helping them choose the right plants for nectar and egg-laying.

critters.name: Dragonfly
critters.fact: Dragonflies can fly in six directions: up, down, forward, backward, and side to side.
critters.activeFact: They catch prey mid-air by forming a basket with their legs, snatching insects on the fly.

critters.name: Damselfly
critters.fact: Damselflies fold their wings along their bodies when resting, unlike dragonflies that keep wings open.
critters.activeFact: They often hover near waterâ€™s edge and perch quietly between short flights, making them easy to overlook.

critters.name: Firefly
critters.fact: Fireflies use bioluminescent light to attract mates and communicate during warm summer nights.
critters.activeFact: Different species blink in distinct patterns, like each one has its own flashing â€œcodeâ€ for finding mates.

critters.name: Honeybee
critters.fact: Honeybees communicate by performing a waggle dance that shows the direction and distance to food sources.
critters.activeFact: They can learn routes and landmarks, helping them return to the hive after long foraging trips.

critters.name: Bumblebee
critters.fact: Bumblebees can regulate their body temperature to fly in cold weather, unlike many other insects.
critters.activeFact: They can â€œbuzz pollinateâ€ by vibrating flowers to shake loose pollen like a tiny living power tool.

critters.name: Grasshopper
critters.fact: Grasshoppers can jump over 20 times their body length using powerful hind legs.
critters.activeFact: Many species make sound by rubbing legs and wings, and each has its own rhythm and tempo.
